holdings.text: The Rent Act and the Requisition Act cannot be considered to be in pari materia as they deal with different subjects: rent control versus requisition of land.

anchor.surface_text: There is absolutely no similarity between the two enactments and we cannot hold that the Requisition Act relates to the same person or thing, or to the same class of persons or things, as the Rent Act. Hence the two Acts cannot be considered to be in pari materia.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rent Act controls landlord-tenant relations, eviction, rent; Requisition Act empowers requisition for public purpose; no overlap in scope or purpose.

holdings.text: Under s.6 of the Requisition Act, an assignment of tenancy rights permissible under the Rent Act is deemed to create a vacancy notwithstanding such permissibility.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 6 of the Requisition Act, notwithstanding the fact that an assignment of tenancy rights may have been made, which is permissible under the Rent Act, such an assignment can be deemed to create a vacancy of the premises, so as to give jurisdiction to the State Government to requisition the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation (a) to s.6 deems vacancy on any assignment/transfer irrespective of Rent Act; cannot read Rent Act prohibition into Requisition Act.

holdings.text: The assignment claimed by the petitioners is a colourable device for obtaining a transfer of tenancy rights prohibited by s.15(1) of the Rent Act and is not saved by clause 2 of the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the view that the assignment, claimed by the petitioners, must be regarded only as a colourable device for really obtaining a transfer of tenancy rights, which is otherwise prohibited by s. 15(1) of the Rent Act. We are further of the view that the transaction, in question, is not saved by clause 2 of the Notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Averments, admissions, change in business (shoes to liquor), object of cl.2 show sham transaction not genuine sale of going concern.

holdings.text: Petitioners cannot claim any rights on the basis of the assignment deed, either in respect of tenancy rights or to carry on business, so no infringement of fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) or (g).

anchor.surface_text: As the petitioners, in our opinion, cannot claim any rights on the basis of the assignment deed, either in respect of tenancy rights, or to carry on any business there, it follows that they cannot complain that any fundamental rights, under Art. 19(1)(f) or (g) of the Constitution, have been infringed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid assignment confers no tenancy or business rights; requisition does not infringe non-existent rights.

holdings.text: The Requisition Act deals only with property and not with trade or business, so Art.19(1)(g) is not attracted.

anchor.surface_text: So far as this is concerned, after a perusal of the entire provisions of the Requisition Act, we are satisfied that the said Act deals only with property and not with trade or business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions concern requisition of land/premises for public purpose, not restriction on trade/occupation.

holdings.text: The State Government has jurisdiction under s.6(4)(a) of the Requisition Act to requisition the premises as a suppressed vacancy.

anchor.surface_text: On September 24, 1966, the second respondent passed an order that the Government of Maharashtra is pleased to declare that the premises, in question, has become vacant after December 4, 1947 and, to requisition the said premises for a public purpose...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Premises vacant in Aug 1964 without intimation; declaration conclusive; deemed vacancy under Explanation(a).

anchor.surface_text: judges in Palmers Case  1785  1 Leach C.C. 4th ed 355, is that such Acts are to be taken together as forming one system, and as interpreting and enforcing each other. In the American case of United Society v. Eagle Bank  1829  7 Conn. 457,470, Hosmer J. said Statutes are in pari materia which relate to the same person or thing or to the same class of persons or things. . . In Maxwell on The Interpretation of Statutes, 11th Edition, at p. 153, the principle is stated thus An author must be supposed to be cisistent with himself, and, therefore, if in one place he has expressed his mind clearly, it ought to be presumed that he is still of the same mind in another place, unless it clearly appears that he has changed it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Acts of Parliament in pari materia are to be taken together as forming one system, and as interpreting and enforcing each other

precedents.citation: United Society v. Eagle Bank  1829  7 Conn. 457,470

anchor.surface_text: In the American case of United Society v. Eagle Bank  1829  7 Conn. 457,470, Hosmer J. said Statutes are in pari materia which relate to the same person or thing or to the same class of persons or things. . . In Maxwell on The Interpretation of Statutes, 11th Edition, at p. 153, the principle is stated thus An author must be supposed to be cisistent with himself, and, therefore, if in one place he has expressed his mind clearly, it ought to be presumed that he is still of the same mind in another place, unless it clearly appears that he has changed it. In this respect, the work of the legislature is treated in the same manner as that of any other author, and the language of every enactment must be construed as far as possible in accordance with the terms of every other statute which it does i

precedents.cited_proposition: Statutes are in pari materia which relate to the same person or thing or to the same class of persons or things

We may straight away say that the principles enunciated in the above decisions and in the text-books, are well-settled. But the question i

precedents.cited_proposition: Court leans in favour of construction that makes provisions consistent with the Constitution
precedents.cited_holding: if certain provisions of law construed in one way would make them consistent with the Constitution, and another interpretation would render them unconstitutional, the Court would lean in favour of the former construction

anchor.surface_text: There is absolutely no similarity between the two enactments and we cannot hold that the Requisition Act relates to the same person or thing, or to the same class of persons or things, as the Rent Act. Hence the two Acts cannot be considered to be in pari materia.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 6 of the Requisition Act, notwithstanding the fact that an assignment of tenancy rights may have been made, which is permissible under the Rent Act, such an assignment can be deemed to create a vacancy of the premises, so as to give jurisdiction to the State Government to requisition the same.
In the result, the writ petition is dismissed with costs of the respondents, one set.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the view that the assignment, claimed by the petitioners, must be regarded only as a colourable device for really obtaining a transfer of tenancy rights, which is otherwise prohibited by s. 15(1) of the Rent Act. We are further of the view that the transaction, in question, is not saved by clause 2 of the Notification.
In the result, the writ petition is dismissed with costs of the respondents, one set.

anchor.surface_text: As the petitioners, in our opinion, cannot claim any rights on the basis of the assignment deed, either in respect of tenancy rights, or to carry on any business there, it follows that they cannot complain that any fundamental rights, under Art. 19(1)(f) or (g) of the Constitution, have been infringed.
In the result, the writ petition is dismissed with costs of the respondents, one set.
